summary: This is an email from a U.S. Department of Justice Attaché in London to colleagues, forwarding a news article and expressing concern about diplomatic strain caused by Prince Andrew's lack of cooperation with the U.S. investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The email discusses the UK's inquiry about Prince Andrew's status as a witness or suspect and the unhelpful public statement from the State Department.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: Duke of York, subject of investigation
persons.context: The central figure whose refusal to cooperate with U.S. investigators into Jeffrey Epstein is causing diplomatic strain between the UK and U.S. He is accused of sexual abuse and is the defendant in a civil lawsuit.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier at the center of the sex trafficking network being investigated. His death in 2019 was ruled a suicide.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges later in 2021. Her prosecution is mentioned as adding further strain to UK-US relations.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: Stated in January 2020 that U.S. authorities had received 'zero cooperation' from Prince Andrew regarding the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Accused Prince Andrew of 'stonewalling' appeals for information in the civil lawsuit filed by his client, who alleges she was sexually abused by the prince.

persons.name: The Ambassador
persons.context: Expressed concern about the news story regarding Prince Andrew and the diplomatic strain, prompting the email author to seek a call with colleagues.

persons.name: U.S. Department of Justice Attaché - London
persons.context: Sent the email forwarding a news article, seeking a call to discuss the diplomatic concerns raised by Prince Andrew's lack of cooperation and the UK's inquiry about his status.

connections.description: Prince Andrew visited Epstein in various locations, including his Caribbean island, and the extent of their ties is of interest to investigators.
Described as Epstein's former girlfriend. She is facing prosecution for sex trafficking charges related to his network.
Giuffre has filed a civil lawsuit alleging Prince Andrew sexually abused her. Prince Andrew has publicly denied the allegations and meeting her.
David Boies is the lawyer representing Virginia Giuffre in her civil lawsuit against Prince Andrew.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in a Manhattan prison; his death was ruled a suicide.

events.title: Prince Andrew's BBC Interview
events.description: Prince Andrew told the BBC he had not had sex with Virginia Giuffre and had no recollection of meeting her.

events.title: Berman's Statement on Lack of Cooperation
events.description: Manhattan U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman stated U.S. authorities had received 'zero cooperation' from Prince Andrew.

events.title: MLA Treaty Application
events.description: The Department of Justice made an application under the US-UK mutual legal assistance treaty to seek cooperation from Prince Andrew.

events.title: Civil Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Virginia Giuffre filed a 15-page civil lawsuit in New York alleging Prince Andrew sexually abused her.

events.title: Maxwell's Upcoming Trial
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is set to go on trial for sex trafficking charges later in the year.

keyFacts: U.S. authorities are frustrated with Prince Andrew's three-year failure to cooperate with the Epstein investigation, causing diplomatic strain between the UK and U.S.
The UK government inquired whether Prince Andrew's status had changed from a witness to a suspect in the criminal investigation following recent allegations.
A U.S. Department of Justice Attaché noted that a public statement from the State Department was 'unhelpful' and likely came from someone 'spouting off'.
Investigators are interested in Prince Andrew's flights to visit Epstein in locations like Little St James, Florida, and New York to understand travel within Epstein's network.
The lack of cooperation is amplified by the unlikelihood of Prince Andrew's extradition, making his voluntary assistance a matter of diplomatic relations.
